com.evernote.android.job

Class JobRequest.Builder

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.evernote.android.job.JobRequest.Builder
  • Enclosing class:
    JobRequest

    public static final class JobRequest.Builder
extends java.lang.Object
    Builder class for constructing JobRequests.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Builder

        public Builder(java.lang.String tag)
        Creates a new instance to build a JobRequest. Note that the tag doesn't need to be unique. Each created request has an unique ID to differentiate between jobs with the same tag.

        When your job is about to start you receive a callback in your JobCreator to create a Job for this tag.
        Parameters:
        tag - The tag is used to identify your Job in JobCreator.create(String).

    • Method Detail

      • setExecutionWindow

        public JobRequest.Builder setExecutionWindow(long startMs,
                                             long endMs)
        Set the time window when the job will be run. Note that it's mandatory to set a time for one-off tasks, but it's not allowed to call this method together with setPeriodic(long) or setExact(long). For those types jobs it doesn't make sense to have a time window.

        The window specified is treated as offset from now, e.g. the job will run between System.currentTimeMillis() + startMs and System.currentTimeMillis() + endMs.
        Parameters:
        startMs - Earliest point from which your task is eligible to run.
        endMs - Latest point at which your task must be run.

      • setExtras

        public JobRequest.Builder setExtras(PersistableBundleCompat extras)
        Set optional extras. This is persisted, so only primitive types are allowed.
        Parameters:
        extras - Bundle containing extras which you can retrieve with Job.Params.getExtras().

      • setRequirementsEnforced

        public JobRequest.Builder setRequirementsEnforced(boolean enforced)
        It's possible to set several requirements for a job, however, not all of them need to be considered by the underlying JobApi. If the requirements are enforced, then the device state is checked before your job runs. If at least one requirement isn't met, then the job is rescheduled and not run.

        It's possible to check single requirements in your job, if you keep this field set to false. The Job class provides several methods, e.g. Job.isRequirementChargingMet().

        Note that it's not allowed to set requirements for exact jobs. That wouldn't make sense, because the job needs to run at a specific time no matter of the device's state.

        The default value is set to false.
        Parameters:
        enforced - If true, then all set requirements are manually checked.

      • setRequiredNetworkType

        public JobRequest.Builder setRequiredNetworkType(JobRequest.NetworkType networkType)
        Set some description of the kind of network type your job needs to have. Not calling this function means the network is not necessary, as the default is JobRequest.NetworkType.ANY.

        Note that if the deadline is met and the requirements aren't enforced, then your job will run and ignore this requirement.
        Parameters:
        networkType - The required network type.
        See Also:
        setRequirementsEnforced(boolean), setExecutionWindow(long, long)

      • setRequiresCharging

        public JobRequest.Builder setRequiresCharging(boolean requiresCharging)
        Specify that to run this job, the device needs to be plugged in. The default is set to false.

        Note that if the deadline is met and the requirements aren't enforced, then your job will run and ignore this requirement.
        Parameters:
        requiresCharging - Whether or not the device needs to be plugged in.
        See Also:
        setRequirementsEnforced(boolean), setExecutionWindow(long, long)

      • setRequiresDeviceIdle

        public JobRequest.Builder setRequiresDeviceIdle(boolean requiresDeviceIdle)
        Specify that to run, the job needs the device to be in idle mode. This defaults to false. Idle mode is a loose definition provided by the system, which means that the device is not in use, and has not been in use for some time. As such, it is a good time to perform resource heavy jobs.

        Note that if the deadline is met and the requirements aren't enforced, then your job will run and ignore this requirement.
        Parameters:
        requiresDeviceIdle - Whether or not the device needs be idle.
        See Also:
        setRequirementsEnforced(boolean), setExecutionWindow(long, long)

      • setExact

        public JobRequest.Builder setExact(long exactMs)
        Specify that the job should run at an exact time. This type of job must only be used for situations where it is actually required that the alarm go off even while in idle. A reasonable example would be for a calendar notification that should make a sound so the user is aware of it.

        Note that an exact job can't be periodic. It's also not allowed to specify any requirement, the exact timing is the most important requirement for such a job. This method overrides any specified time window.

        The default value is set to false. Internally an exact job is always using the AlarmManager.

        The milliseconds specified are treated as offset from now, e.g. the job will run at System.currentTimeMillis() + exactMs.
        Parameters:
        exactMs - The exact offset when the job should run from when the job was scheduled.
        See Also:
        AlarmManager.setExact(int, long, android.app.PendingIntent), AlarmManager.setExactAndAllowWhileIdle(int, long, android.app.PendingIntent)

      • setPeriodic

        public JobRequest.Builder setPeriodic(long intervalMs)
        This job should run one time during each interval. As default a job isn't periodic.

        It isn't allowed to specify a time window for a periodic job. Instead you set an interval with this function. Since Job.Result.RESCHEDULE is ignored for periodic jobs, setting a back-off criteria is illegal as well.
        Parameters:
        intervalMs - The job should at most once every intervalMs.

      • setBackoffCriteria

        public JobRequest.Builder setBackoffCriteria(long backoffMs,
                                             JobRequest.BackoffPolicy backoffPolicy)
        Change the back-off policy for a non periodic job. The default value is set to 30 seconds and JobRequest.BackoffPolicy.EXPONENTIAL. The time is increasing each time a job fails and returns Job.Result.RESCHEDULE, but capped at 5 hours.

        Note that it's not allowed to change the back-off criteria for a periodic job.
        Parameters:
        backoffMs - The initial interval to wait when the job has been rescheduled.
        backoffPolicy - Is either JobRequest.BackoffPolicy.LINEAR or JobRequest.BackoffPolicy.EXPONENTIAL.
        See Also:
        Job.Result.RESCHEDULE, Job.onReschedule(int)

      • setPersisted

        public JobRequest.Builder setPersisted(boolean persisted)
        Set whether the job should be persisted across reboots. This will only have an effect if your application holds the permission Manifest.permission.RECEIVE_BOOT_COMPLETED. Otherwise an exception will be thrown. The default is set to false.
        Parameters:
        persisted - If true the job is scheduled after a reboot.

      • setUpdateCurrent

        public JobRequest.Builder setUpdateCurrent(boolean updateCurrent)
        Sets whether this request should overwrite any preexisting jobs with the same tag. If true, then this request calls JobManager.cancelAllForTag(String) with the given tag before being scheduled.
        Parameters:
        updateCurrent - If {code true} this request will cancel any preexisting job with the same tag while being scheduled.

      • build

        public JobRequest build()
        Returns:
        The JobRequest with this parameters to hand to the JobManager.
